question: A.1 (1.00) Given a source strength of 100 neutrons per second (N/sec) and a multiplication factor of 0.8, the expected neutron count rate would be:

A.2 (1.00) With the reactor critical at 10 KW a rod is pulled to insert a positive reactivity of 0.00126 K/K. Which one of the following will be the stable reactor period as a result of this reactivity insertion?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: T = ( - )/ eff = .0075 - .00126 = 49.5 seconds
Correct. REF: T = ( - )/ eff = .0075 - .00126 = 49.5 seconds
Incorrect. REF: T = ( - )/ eff = .0075 - .00126 = 49.5 seconds
Incorrect. REF: T = ( - )/ eff = .0075 - .00126 = 49.5 seconds

question: A.3 (1.00) An initial count rate of 100 is doubled five times during a startup. Assuming an initial Keff of 0.950, which one of the following is the new Keff?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: CR1 (1-Keff1) = CR2 (1 - Keff2
Incorrect. REF: CR1 (1-Keff1) = CR2 (1 - Keff2).
Incorrect. REF: CR1 (1-Keff1) = CR2 (1 - Keff2).
Correct. REF: CR1 (1-Keff1) = CR2 (1 - Keff2).

question: A.4 (1.00) Consider two identical critical reactors, with the exception that one has a beta of 0.0072 and the other has a beta of 0.0060. Each reactor is operating at 10 watts. Which one of the following compares the response of the reactors to a +0.1% delta k/k reactivity insertion?

answers.answer: a. The resulting period will be shorter for the reactor with the 0.0072 beta fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: b. The resulting period will be shorter for the reactor with the 0.0060 beta fraction
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: c. The resulting power level will be higher for the reactor with the 0.0072 beta fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: d. The resulting power level will be higher for the reactor with the 0.0060 beta fraction
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

question: A.5 (2.00, 0.5 each) Match the terms in column A with the correct definition in column B

B.definition: 3. Neutrons released from decay after fission.

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 3.2.2 Delayed Neutrons.
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 3.2.2 Delayed Neutrons.
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 3.2.2 Delayed Neutrons.

pairing.definition: 3. Neutrons released from decay after fission.

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 3.2.2 Delayed Neutrons.

question: A.6 (1.00) The reactor is critical and increasing in power. Power has increased from 20 watts to 80 watts in 60 seconds. How long will it take at this rate for power to increase from 0.080 KW to 160 KW?

answers.feedback: Incorrect.REFERENCE: P = P₀e^(t/T); 80 = 20e^(60/T), T = 43.28 sec. For 160 KW: 1.6 x 10^5 watts = 80e^(t/43.28), t = 329 sec = 5.5 minutes.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P₀e^(t/T); 80 = 20e^(60/T), T = 43.28 sec. For 160 KW: 1.6 x 10^5 watts = 80e^(t/43.28), t = 329 sec = 5.5 minutes.
Correct. REFERENCE: P = P₀e^(t/T); 80 = 20e^(60/T), T = 43.28 sec. For 160 KW: 1.6 x 10^5 watts = 80e^(t/43.28), t = 329 sec = 5.5 minutes.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P₀e^(t/T); 80 = 20e^(60/T), T = 43.28 sec. For 160 KW: 1.6 x 10^5 watts = 80e^(t/43.28), t = 329 sec = 5.5 minutes.

question: A.7 (1.00) A reactor with an initial population of 24000 neutrons is operating with Keff = 1.01. Of the CHANGE in population from the current generation to the next generation, how many are prompt neutrons?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: 24000 x 1.01 = 24240 neutrons in next generation. 24240 - 24000 = 240 neutrons added, minus 0.7% delayed neutron fraction = 238 prompt neutrons added.
Correct. REFERENCE: 24000 x 1.01 = 24240 neutrons in next generation. 24240 - 24000 = 240 neutrons added, minus 0.7% delayed neutron fraction = 238 prompt neutrons added.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: 24000 x 1.01 = 24240 neutrons in next generation. 24240 - 24000 = 240 neutrons added, minus 0.7% delayed neutron fraction = 238 prompt neutrons added.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: 24000 x 1.01 = 24240 neutrons in next generation. 24240 - 24000 = 240 neutrons added, minus 0.7% delayed neutron fraction = 238 prompt neutrons added.

question: A.8 (1.00) Which one of the following conditions would INCREASE the shutdown margin of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Inserting an experiment adding positive reactivity.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.

answers.answer: b. Lowering moderator temperature if the moderator temperature coefficient is negative.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.

answers.answer: c. Depletion of a burnable poison.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.

question: A.9 (1.00) Which one of the following is the PRIMARY reason that delayed neutrons are so effective at controlling reactor power?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons make up a very large fraction of the fission neutrons in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons have a much longer mean lifetime than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons are born at thermal energies.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are born at lower energies than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

question: A.10 (1.00) Which one of the following is the principal source of heat in the reactor after a shutdown from extended operation at 1 MW?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.

answers.answer: b. Kinetic energy of fission fragments
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 4.9, pp. 4-23 — 4-26.

question: A.11 (1.00) The following data was obtained during a reactor fuel load. No. of Elements: 0, 8, 16, 24, 32, 40; Detector A (cps): 20, 28, 30, 32, 42, 80. Which one of the following represents the number of fuel elements predicted to reach criticality?

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.5, pp. 5-18 — 5-25.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.5, pp. 5-18 — 5-25.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.5, pp. 5-18 — 5-25.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.5, pp. 5-18 — 5-25.

question: A.12 (1.00) Following 8 hours at 1 MW, the reactor operator reduces reactor power to 50%. Rod control is placed in manual mode and all rod motion is stopped. Which one of the following describes the response of reactor power, without any further operator actions, and the PRIMARY reason for its response?

answers.answer: a. Power increases due to the burnout of xenon.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 — 8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

answers.answer: b. Power increases due to the burnout of samarium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 — 8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

answers.answer: c. Power decreases due to the buildup of xenon.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 — 8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

answers.answer: d. Power decreases due to the buildup of samarium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 — 8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

question: A.13 (1.00) Which one of the following is a correct statement concerning the factors affecting control rod worth?

answers.answer: a. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth for periphery rods to decrease.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

answers.answer: b. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth to increase in the center of the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

answers.answer: c. The withdrawal of a rod causes the rod worth of the remaining inserted rods to increase.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

answers.answer: d. As Rx power increases rod worth increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

question: A.14 (1.00) Pool temperature increases by 20F. Given Tmoderator = -0.0005 K/K/F and an average regulating rod worth of 0.004 K/K/inch. By how much and in what direction did the regulating rod move to compensate for the temperature change?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: +20F × -0.0005 K/K/F = -0.01 K/K. To compensate, the rod must add +0.01 K/K. +0.01 K/K ÷ +0.004 K/K/inch = +2.5 inches.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: +20F × -0.0005 K/K/F = -0.01 K/K. To compensate, the rod must add +0.01 K/K. +0.01 K/K ÷ +0.004 K/K/inch = +2.5 inches.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: +20F × -0.0005 K/K/F = -0.01 K/K. To compensate, the rod must add +0.01 K/K. +0.01 K/K ÷ +0.004 K/K/inch = +2.5 inches.
Correct. REFERENCE: +20F × -0.0005 K/K/F = -0.01 K/K. To compensate, the rod must add +0.01 K/K. +0.01 K/K ÷ +0.004 K/K/inch = +2.5 inches.

question: A.15 (1.00) Which ONE of the following statements describes the subcritical reactor response as Keff approaches unity?

answers.answer: a. A LARGER change in neutron level results from a given change in Keff and a SHORTER period of time is required to reach the equilibrium neutron level for a given change in Keff.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

answers.answer: b. A LARGER change in neutron level results from a given change in Keff and a LONGER period of time is required to reach the equilibrium neutron level for a given change in Keff.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

answers.answer: c. A SMALLER change in neutron level results from a given change in Keff and a SHORTER period of time is required to reach the equilibrium neutron level for a given change in Keff.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

answers.answer: d. A SMALLER change in neutron level results from a given change in Keff and a LONGER period of time is required to reach the equilibrium neutron level for a given change in Keff.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Chapt. 5, pp. 5-1 — 5-28.

question: A.16 (1.00) An experiment to be placed in the central thimble has been wrapped in cadmium. Which one of the following types of radiation will be most effectively blocked by the cadmium wrapping?

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 10.34, pp. 639.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 10.34, pp. 639.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 10.34, pp. 639.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 10.34, pp. 639.

question: A.17 (1.00) A thin foil target of 10% copper atoms and 90% aluminum atoms is in a thermal neutron beam. Given σ_Al = 3.79 barns, σ_Cu = 0.23 barns, α_Al = 7.90 barns, and α_Cu = 1.49 barns, which ONE of the following reactions has the highest probability of occurring? A neutron...

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 2.108 – 2.114, pp. 77 – 80.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 2.108 – 2.114, pp. 77 – 80.
Correct. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 2.108 – 2.114, pp. 77 – 80.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 2.108 – 2.114, pp. 77 – 80.

question: A.18 (1.00) The reactor is operating at 500 KW in steady-state and in manual mode. Which one of the following describes the stable reactor period if a control rod drops fully into the core and no operator action is taken?

answers.answer: a. -34 seconds due to the rapid decrease in prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: The amount of reactivity inserted by the blade is much larger than beta; therefore, maximum stable negative period of -80 seconds results.

answers.answer: b. -34 seconds due to the rapid decay of the short-lived delayed neutron precursors
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: The amount of reactivity inserted by the blade is much larger than beta; therefore, maximum stable negative period of -80 seconds results.

answers.answer: c. -80 seconds due to the slowing down length of prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: The amount of reactivity inserted by the blade is much larger than beta; therefore, maximum stable negative period of -80 seconds results.

answers.answer: d. -80 seconds due to the decay half-life of the long-lived delayed neutron precursors
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: The amount of reactivity inserted by the blade is much larger than beta; therefore, maximum stable negative period of -80 seconds results.

question: A.19 (1.00) Which one of the following factors in the 'six factor' formula is the most strongly affected by the Negative Temperature Coefficient?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 5.98, p. 264.
Correct. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 5.98, p. 264.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 5.98, p. 264.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, 1991, § 5.98, p. 264.
